claim: All United States Aldi locations are owned by the same company.

supporting.text: Aldi operates as a single corporate entity in the United States under Aldi US, which manages all its locations nationwide.

attacks.text: Aldi operates as a single corporate entity in the United States under Aldi US, which manages all its locations nationwide.
Aldi US is actually split into two separate divisions, Aldi Nord and Aldi Sud, which operate independently in different regions of the United States.
While Aldi Nord and Aldi Sud exist globally, in the United States, only Aldi Sud operates under the name Aldi, with Aldi Nord operating as Trader Joe's.
Aldi US is a single legal entity that consolidates all Aldi-branded stores in the United States under one management structure, regardless of historical divisions.

supporting.text: All Aldi stores in the U.S. follow the same branding, pricing, and operational standards, indicating centralized ownership.

attacks.text: All Aldi stores in the U.S. follow the same branding, pricing, and operational standards, indicating centralized ownership.
Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd operate as separate companies globally, including in the U.S., despite similar branding.
Aldi Nord owns Trader Joe's in the U.S., while Aldi Süd operates under the Aldi name, proving decentralized ownership.
Uniform branding and standards can result from franchising or licensing agreements, not necessarily centralized ownership.
Aldi explicitly denies franchising and maintains direct control over all U.S. stores, supporting centralized management.

supporting.text: Aldi's U.S. expansion strategy is managed by a unified corporate structure, with no evidence of franchise or independent ownership models.

attacks.text: Aldi's U.S. expansion strategy is managed by a unified corporate structure, with no evidence of franchise or independent ownership models.
Some Aldi locations in the U.S. are operated under regional subsidiaries, which may imply decentralized ownership structures.
Regional subsidiaries are still wholly owned by the parent company, maintaining unified corporate ownership.
Historical records show Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd operate separately in the U.S., meaning not all locations are owned by the same entity.
Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd operate under distinct branding (Trader Joe's vs. Aldi) in the U.S., so the claim only applies to Aldi-branded stores.

supporting.text: Financial and supply chain operations for Aldi in the U.S. are coordinated by a single parent company, ensuring uniformity across all locations.

attacks.text: Financial and supply chain operations for Aldi in the U.S. are coordinated by a single parent company, ensuring uniformity across all locations.
Aldi in the U.S. is split into two separate companies, Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd, which operate independently under different parent companies.
While Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd operate independently, they share branding and supply chain strategies, creating the appearance of a single entity.
Some Aldi locations in the U.S. are franchised, meaning they are owned by individual operators rather than a single parent company.
Franchised Aldi locations are still required to adhere to strict corporate standards, maintaining operational uniformity.

supporting.text: Public records and business registrations confirm that Aldi U.S. is the sole legal owner of all its retail locations in the country.

attacks.text: Public records and business registrations confirm that Aldi U.S. is the sole legal owner of all its retail locations in the country.
Some Aldi locations may operate under franchise agreements, which would mean they are not directly owned by Aldi U.S.
Aldi has a strict company policy against franchising and only operates corporate-owned stores in the U.S.
Public records may not always reflect recent changes in ownership or corporate restructuring.
Aldi U.S. maintains transparent and up-to-date business registrations with state authorities.
